headline: Sarasota's school district must wake up - and fight back | Opinion
context: I am writing in response to the April 27 guest column by Sarasota County Schools Superintendent Terry Connor, “Sarasota schools ready to meet challenges in education – and emerge stronger."
While I personally supported Connor’s hiring and applaud much of the work he has done in Sarasota County, it is time for a bit of a reality check.

annotations.paragraph: We at Support Our Schools are thrilled that Connor says that “Sarasota County Schools will not quietly absorb the consequences of policy decisions made by many lawmakers."
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct quote from Connor, which is relevant to the discussion about the school district's response to policy decisions.

annotations.paragraph: But is this too little, too late?
annotations.reason: This paragraph poses a rhetorical question without providing new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: This is not just an issue of the current Legislature: The state of Florida has been underfunding public education for decades. It started in 1999 with Gov. Jeb Bush and the first go-round with vouchers and tax credit scholarships, and moved on to Step Up for Students and Education Scholarships.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context about the underfunding of public education in Florida, which is relevant to the main issue.

annotations.paragraph: This eventually led to the 2023 universal voucher bill, which cost Florida nearly $4 billion during the 2024-25 school year. Those costs will only grow exponentially in the future, taking more funds out of our public schools.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about the financial impact of recent legislation, which is relevant to the article's focus on funding issues.

annotations.paragraph: Why is it only now that our school district has decided to stand up and fight back against budget cuts and poor policy choices by the executive and legislative branches?
annotations.reason: This paragraph questions the timing of the school district's response, which is relevant to the article's critique of the district's actions.

annotations.paragraph: My co-founders and I formed the nonprofit organization Support Our Schools in 2022.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides background information about the author's organization, which is relevant to the context of the article.

annotations.paragraph: We are one of those “local coalitions” that Connor alluded to – the David standing up against the Goliath of dark money organizations like the Heritage Foundation and Project 2025.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the author's organization and its opposition, which is relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: When we formed, we quickly saw the writing on the wall.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is vague and does not provide specific information relevant to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: It wasn’t really about the culture war dog whistles like critical race theory, social and emotional learning and "Don’t Say Gay." They were just distractions to keep people from realizing the real goal: the destruction of public education by underfunding and defunding through vouchers.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a critical perspective on the issues facing public education, which is relevant to the article's main argument.

annotations.paragraph: When we talk about school choice, we must understand that it isn’t the students and parents who have the choice when it comes to private schools and, to a certain extent, for-profit managed charter schools.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a critical viewpoint on school choice, contributing to the article's discussion on education policy.

annotations.paragraph: It is the schools who exercise the choice of who they accept or reject.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a fact about school admission policies relevant to the discussion on school choice.

annotations.paragraph: Remember, you sign away your civil rights and your child’s IEP or 504 plan when you go to a private school. If they don’t like you because of your race, religion or any other reason, the private schools can make the choice to reject your application or, if you have already been admitted, remove you and send you back to the public schools.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers important context about the implications of choosing private schools, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: And as Connor correctly pointed out, there is no transparency or accountability related to performance or fiduciary responsibility in these for-profit managed charters and private schools.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a critical point about the lack of accountability in private schools, directly related to the article's argument.

annotations.paragraph: Putting aside Connor’s “. . . this isn’t austerity. It’s smart reinvestment” rhetoric, it’s time for some straightforward reality: Our legislators, who are still more than $4 billion apart on the budget reconciliation, are willfully choosing to use our tax dollars to fund the wealthy who already have their kids in private schools.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the financial implications of current legislative decisions, relevant to the article's critique.

annotations.paragraph: (For example, did you know that 70% of vouchers go to students already enrolled in private schools?)
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a specific statistic that supports the article's argument about funding allocation.

annotations.paragraph: You don’t need to be a certified public accountant to figure out that if you’re cutting tax revenues while also pulling more money out of the public schools to fund vouchers and for-profit managed charter schools, something must give.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant context about financial challenges facing Sarasota's public schools.

annotations.paragraph: And in this case, it is going to translate into major cuts in our public schools.
annotations.reason: This paragraph directly relates to the impact of financial decisions on Sarasota's public schools.

annotations.paragraph: Our children are the ones paying the price of this betrayal of the public trust.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a perspective on the consequences of financial decisions on students.

annotations.paragraph: Yes, Mr. Connor, we must be "optimistic," but we must also be realistic.
annotations.reason: This paragraph critiques the superintendent's stance, contributing to the opinion piece.

annotations.paragraph: No matter how much lipstick you put on a pig, it’s still a pig.
annotations.reason: This paragraph uses a metaphor to emphasize the author's critical view, adding to the opinion.

annotations.paragraph: Our greatest concern is that those most impacted by these “difficult decisions” will be those students for whom public education presents the best or, in some cases, the only option.
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights the potential negative impact of decisions on students reliant on public education, directly relating to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: These are the kids we are fighting for every day.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a vague generalization without new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: The private schools do not want to educate our special education students because that is not a profitable endeavor. Nor do they want to provide career and technical education opportunities in trade schools, because the profit margin isn’t large enough.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific commentary on private schools' reluctance to serve certain students, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: When you start adding a profit motive into education, that money is coming right out of our children’s public-school funding and is going straight into the school owner’s pocket.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the financial implications of profit motives in education, relevant to the article's argument.

annotations.paragraph: What can we, the citizens of Sarasota, do to stop this outflow?
annotations.reason: This paragraph poses a question about community action, relevant to the article's call to action.

annotations.paragraph: The first thing is to educate ourselves about what the impact of all these cuts to our public education budget will do. You can learn more by visiting our website or by visiting the website of the Network for Public Education at networkforpubliceducation.org. The Florida Policy Institute also provides a wealth of information at floridapolicy.org.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides general advice and external resources, which is not directly related to the main premise.

annotations.paragraph: The next step is getting involved in advocating for more funding for public education with our legislators. And you can use your vote at the ballot box to elect pro-public education candidates.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers general advocacy advice without specific details related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: If our School Board and administration are finally willing to take action against underfunding and bad education policies, that is truly something to be optimistic about. And Support Our Schools will be here to support you and the board, Superintendent Connor, when you fight back.
annotations.reason: This paragraph directly addresses the school district's potential actions and support, aligning with the headline's call to action.

annotations.paragraph: We’ve been doing it for the last four years, and we do not intend to stop now.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a vague statement about ongoing efforts without new information.

annotations.paragraph: Lisa Schurr is the director of Support Our Schools.
annotations.reason: This is a background detail about the author, not directly related to the main premise.
